CROSS REFERENCES
      See sectional histories for similar State law
      Statute of limitations on prosecutions - see Ohio R. C. 718.06; GEN. OFF.
501.06
      Codification in book form - see Ohio R. C. 731.23
      Imprisonment until fine and costs are paid - see Ohio R. C. 1905.30,
2947.20
      Citation issuance for minor misdemeanors - see Ohio R. C. 2935.26 et seq.
      Ordinances and resolutions - see ADM. Ch.
123
      Rules of construction for offenses and penalties - see GEN. OFF.
501.04
   101.01  DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (a)    All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of Macedonia, Ohio, 1983 for which designation "Codified
Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, title, chapter and section headings do
not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
   (b)    All references to codes, titles, chapters and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code".
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section" followed by
the number, such as "Section
101.01".
   101.02  GENERAL DEFINITIONS .
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)    "And" may be read "or", and "or" may be read "and", if the sense
requires it. (ORC 1.02 (F))
   (b)    "Another" when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property. (ORC 1.02 (B))
   (c)    "Bond" includes an undertaking and "undertaking" includes a bond.
      (ORC 1.02 (D), (E))
   (d)    "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (e)    "County" means Summit County, Ohio.
   (f)    "Keeper" or "proprietor" includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent or employee.
   (g)    "Land" or "real estate" includes rights and easements of an
incorporeal nature. (ORC 701.01 (F))
   (h)    "Municipality" or "City" means the municipality of Macedonia, Ohio.
   (i)    "Oath" includes affirmation and "swear" includes affirm. (ORC 1.59
(B))
   (j)    "Owner", when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint
owner or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (k)    "Person" includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership and association. (ORC 1.59(C))
   (l)    "Premises", as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   (m)    "Property" means real and personal property. (ORC 1.59(E))
      "Personal property" includes all property except real.
      "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   (n)    "Public authority" includes boards of education; the Municipal,
County, State or Federal government, its officers or an agency thereof; or any
duly authorized public official.
   (o)    "Public place" includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   (p)    "Registered mail" includes certified mail and "certified mail"
includes registered mail. (ORC 1.02(G))
   (q)    "Rule" includes regulation. (ORC 1.59(F))
   (r)    "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   (s)    "This State" or "the State" means the State of Ohio. (ORC 1.59(G))
   (t)    "Street" includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads,
highways, viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (u)    "Tenant" or "occupant", as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
   (v)    "Whoever" includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals,  agents and employees; and all officials, public or private. (ORC
1.02(A))
   (w)    "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words,
letters, symbols  or figures. This provision does not affect any law relating
to signatures.
      (ORC 1.59(J))
   101.03  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)    Common and Technical Usage.  Words and phrases shall be read in
context and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words
and phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly. (ORC 1.42)
   (b)    Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense.  As used in the Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
      (1)    The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)    Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)    Words in the present tense include the future. (ORC 1.43)
   (c)    Calendar; Computation of Time.
      (1)    Definitions.
         A.    "Week" means seven consecutive days.
         B.    "Year" means twelve consecutive months.
            (ORC 1.44)
      (2)    If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months
from a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the
concluding month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun,
unless there are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the
period ends on the last day of that month.
         (ORC 1.45)
      (3)    The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall
be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday. When a public
office, in which an act required by law is to be performed, is closed to the
public for the entire day which constitutes the last day for doing such act or
before its usual closing time on such day, then such act may be performed on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday. If any legal
holiday falls on Sunday, the next succeeding day is a legal holiday.
         (ORC 1.14)
      (4)    When legislation is to take effect or become operative from and
after a day named, no part of that day shall be included. (ORC 1.15)
      (5)    In all cases where the law shall require any act to be done in a
reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or
notice shall mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance
of such duty or compliance with such notice. 
   (d)    Authority.  When the law requires an act to be done which may by law
as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent.
   (e)    Joint Authority.  All words purporting to give joint authority to
three or more municipal officers or other persons shall be construed as giving
such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it shall
be otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority or inconsistent
with State statute or Charter provisions.
   (f)   Exceptions.  The rules of construction shall not apply to any law
which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when
the subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
   101.04  REVIVOR; EFFECT OF AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)    The repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive the ordinance
originally repealed nor impair the effect of any saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)    An ordinance which is re-enacted or amended is intended to be a
continuation of the prior ordinance and not a new enactment, so far as it is
the same as the prior ordinance. (ORC 1.54)
   (c)    The re-enactment, amendment or repeal of an ordinance does not,
except as provided in subsection (d) hereof:
      (1)    Affect the prior operation of the ordinance or any prior action
taken thereunder;
      (2)    Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded or incurred thereunder;
      (3)    Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
      (4)    Affect any investigation, proceeding or remedy in respect of any
such privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and
the investigation, proceeding or remedy may be instituted, continued or
enforced, and the penalty, forfeiture or punishment imposed, as if the
ordinance had not been repealed or amended.
   
   (d)    If the penalty, forfeiture or punishment for any offense is reduced
by a re- enactment or amendment of an ordinance, the penalty, forfeiture or
punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according to the ordinance
as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
   101.05  CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)    A reference to any portion of the Codified Ordinances applies to all
re- enactments or amendments thereof. (ORC 1.55)
   (b)    If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters are included.
(ORC 1.56)
   (¢)    Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections or of subsections of a section, such reference shall be
construed to mean a violation  of any section or subsection included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
   101.06  CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   (a)    If there is a conflict between figures and words in expressing a
number, the words govern. (ORC 1.46)
   (b)    If a general provision conflicts with a special or local provision,
they shall be construed, if possible, so that effect is given to both. If the
conflict between the provisions is irreconcilable, the special or local
provision prevails as an exception to the general provision, unless the general
provision is the later adoption and the manifest intent is that the general
provision prevail. (ORC 1.51)
   (c)    (1)    If ordinances enacted at different meetings of Council are
irreconcilable, the ordinance latest in date of enactment prevails.
      (2)    If amendments to the same ordinance are enacted at different
meetings of  Council, one amendment without reference to another, the
amendments are to be harmonized, if possible, so that effect may be given to
each. If the amendments are substantively irreconcilable, the latest in date of
enactment prevails. The fact that a later amendment restates language deleted
by an earlier amendment, or fails to include language inserted by an earlier
amendment, does not of itself make the amendments irreconcilable. Amendments
are irreconcilable only when changes made by each cannot reasonably be put into
simultaneous operation.
         (ORC 1.52)
   101.07  DETERMINATION OF LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
    (a)    In enacting an ordinance, it is presumed that:
      (1)    Compliance with the constitutions of the State and of the United
States is  intended;
      (2)    The entire ordinance is intended to be effective;
      (3)    A just and reasonable result is intended;
      (4)    A result feasible of execution is intended.
         (ORC 1.47)
   (b)    An ordinance is presumed to be prospective in its operation unless
expressly made retrospective. (ORC 1.48)
   (c)    If an ordinance is ambiguous, the court, in determining the intention
of Council
may consider among other matters:
      (1)    The object sought to be attained;
      (2)    The circumstances under which the ordinance was enacted;
      (3)    The legislative history;
      (4)    The common law or former legislative provisions, including laws
upon the same or similar subjects;
      (5)    The consequences of a particular construction;
      (6)    The administrative construction of the ordinance.
         (ORC 1.49)
   101.08  SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect the other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
   101.99  GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be punished by a
fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day during or on which a violation continues or occurs.
CHAPTER 103
Official Standards
   EDITOR'S NOTE: There are no sections in Chapter 103. This chapter has been
established to provide a place for cross references and future legislation.

CHAPTER 105
Open Meetings
105.01   Definitions.
105.02   Notice of regular meetings.
105.03   Special meetings.
105.04   Notice to news media of special meetings.   
105.05   Notification of discussion of specific types of public business.
105.06   Requests for general  information.
105.07   Attempt.
CROSS REFERENCES
State provisions - see Ohio R.C. 121.22(F)
   105.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Clerk" means the Clerk of Council of the City, or the clerk or
secretary of any board, commission or other agency in the Municipality.
   (b)    "Day" means calendar day.
   (c)    "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business of
the Municipal Body by a majority of the members of the Municipal Body.
   (d)    "Municipal Body" means Council, Planning Commission, Board of Zoning
and Building Code Appeals, the Civil Service Commission, the Architectural
Board and such other bodies as are determined to be included within the Ohio
Statutes embodied in what is commonly known as the "Sunshine Law. "
   (e)    "Oral notification" means notification by word of mouth, whether in
direct confrontation, or by telephone, or by leaving an oral message for such
person at his usual telephone number, whether it be his residence or his usual
trade, occupation or business.
   (f)    "Post" means to post in an area at City Hall accessible to the public
during the usual business hours of the City.
   (g)    "Published" means published once in a newspaper having a general
circulation in the Municipality as defined in Ohio R.C. 7.12 except that no
portion of such newspaper need be printed in the Municipality.
   (h)    "Special meeting" means a meeting which is neither a regular meeting
nor an adjournment of a regular meeting.
   (i)    "Written notification" means notification in writing mailed,
telegraphed or hand delivered to the address of a person for whom such notice
is intended.
   (j)    "Mailed notice" is further defined as notification mailed to the
person intended to receive it no later than the second day preceding the day of
the meeting.
(Res. 85-1975. Passed 1-22-76.)
   105.02  NOTICE OF REGULAR MEETING.
   (a)    The Clerk of Council or the clerk or secretary of each board or
commission shall post a statement of the time and place of regular meetings of
such Municipal Body for each calendar year not later than the second day
preceding the day of the first regular meeting of the calendar year of the
Municipal Body and, shall check at reasonable intervals to insure that such
date remains so posted during such calendar year. Revisions of meeting dates
for regular meetings, must be changed immediately on such posted statement by
the Clerk at her first reasonable opportunity during normal business hours.
   (b)    The Clerk or secretary shall post a statement of the time and place
of any organizational meeting of a Municipal Body at least twenty-four hours
before the time of such organizational meeting.
   (c)    Upon the adjournment of any regular or special meeting to another
day, the Clerk shall at her first opportunity during normal business hours
promptly post notice of time and place of such adjourned meeting. (Res. 85-
1975. Passed 1-22-76.)
   105.03  SPECIAL  MEETINGS.
   (a)    Except in a case of a special meeting referred to in Section
105.04, the Clerk shall no later than twenty-four hours before the time of a
special meeting of the Municipal Body, post a statement of time, place and
purpose of such special meeting.
   (b)    A statement as to special meetings, posted by the Clerk or secretary,
shall state the specific general purpose or purposes then known to the Clerk or
secretary to be intended to be considered at such special meeting and, may
state as an additional general purpose, that any other business as may be
properly before such Body, Board or Commission, may be considered and acted
upon. (Res. 85-1975, Passed 1-22-76.)
   105.04  NOTICE TO NEWS MEDIA OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)    Any news medium organization that desires to be given advance
notification of special meetings of a Municipal Body shall file with the Clerk
a written request therefor on a form to be provided by the Clerk.
   (b)    Except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official
action, a special meeting shall not be held unless at least twenty-four hours
advance notice of time, place and the purpose of such special meeting is given
to the news media that have requested such advance notification.
   (c)    News media requests for such advance notification of special meetings
shall specify the Municipal Body that is the subject of such request, the name
of the medium, the name and address of the person to whom written notification
to the medium may be mailed, telegraphed or delivered. Such written request by
the news medium shall be effective for six months and for additional periods of
six months after each such request for news medium notification has been filed
with the Clerk.
   (d)    The Clerk or secretary shall give such oral notification or written
notification or both as the Clerk determines to the news media that have
requested such advance notification at least twenty-four hours prior to the
time of such special meeting.
   (e)    In the event of an emergency meeting, wherein it is essential to hold
a meeting and take immediate action, the Clerk or secretary shall make a
reasonable effort to notify the news medium that has filed such request form,
orally, or by writing delivered. The minutes of any emergency meeting shall
state the general nature of the emergency involved.
(Res. 85-1975. Passed 1-22-76.)
   105.05  NOTIFICATION OF DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC TYPES OF  PUBLIC BUSINESS.
   (a)    Any person upon written request as provided herein may obtain
reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which specific type of
public business is scheduled to be discussed upon filing a written request with
the Clerk or secretary specifying the person's name, address, telephone number
or numbers, the specific type of public business of which the person is
requesting advance notification, the Municipal Body that is the subject of such
request, and the number of months, not to exceed three, which the request
covers. Such request may be canceled by the person upon notification to the
Clerk or secretary.
   (b)    Each such written request must be accompanied by cash or a check
payable to the City in the amount of one dollar ($1.00) for each month covered
by the request which amount has been determined by Council to represent a
reasonable fee to cover costs of providing such advance notification. The Clerk
shall not be responsible for change of address or change of telephone number
without notification to the Clerk or secretary.
   (c)    The Clerk shall give advance notice of discussion of specific types
of public business under subsection (a) hereof, either in writing or orally, if
there is doubt as to the receipt of written notice in time for such meeting.
(Res. 85-1975. Passed 1-22-76.)
   105.06  REQUESTS FOR GENERAL INFORMATION.
   The Clerk shall respond to oral or written requests for information
concerning regular, special or emergency meetings and indicate to the inquirer
the time, date, place and subject of any such meeting in accordance with
information available to such Clerk.
(Res. 85-1975. Passed 1-22-76.)
   105.07  ATTEMPT.
   The requirements of actual notice of any regular, special or emergency
meeting shall have been complied with if the Clerk makes a reasonable attempt
at such notice. No action by any Body, Board or Commission shall be invalid if
there is a reasonable attempt at actual notice by the Clerk.
(Res. 85-1975. Passed 1-22-76.)

            Chap.

CHAPTER 121
Council
121.01   Meetings.
121.02   Rules and regulations.
121.03   Assistant Clerk of Council.
121.04   Roberts' Rules of Order.
121.05   Use of Internet auctions to dispose of City property.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Composition, term and qualifications - see CHTR. §
4.02
      Rules and Journal - see CHTR. §

      Meetings - see CHTR. §

103
   121.01 MEETINGS.
   (a)    Council shall meet in regular session in Council Chambers, on the
second
and fourth Thursdays of each month at 7:30 p.m. Should any holiday fall upon
the date
for a regular meeting, Council shall meet on the day established by motion of
Council
at any meeting prior to such holiday.
(Ord. 18-1970. Passed 6-25-70; Ord. 10-76. Passed 2-12-76. )
   (b)    The Mayor, or any three members of Council may call special meetings
of Council upon at least twelve hours notice to each member, served personally
or left at the member's usual place of residence.
(Ord. 18-1970. Passed 6-25-70.)
   (c)    When there is reason to believe that the number of persons desiring
to attend a session of Council shall exceed the permitted seating capacity of
the Council Chambers, the Mayor or the Fire Chief shall advise the members of
Council of such condition and shall make arrangements to hold that session of
Council at a time and place capable of seating the number of persons
anticipated. If the Mayor or Fire Chief determines that the Council session
must be moved from the Council Chambers, the Mayor or Fire Chief shall insure
that each member of Council is informed of the change with at least twenty-four
hours notice and shall insure that the public is likewise informed of such
change. In addition, the Mayor or Fire Chief shall post a notice at the Council
Chambers of any such change of a Council session.
(Ord. 49-1990. Passed 4-12-90.)
   121.02  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)    Agenda.  The Mayor shall prepare an agenda or schedule of matters to
be brought before Council. The agenda shall be given to the members of Council,
the Mayor, the Law Director and Department Heads, just before the meeting, or,
if possible, mailed to them at least one day before the meeting.
   (b)    Call to Order.  The Mayor, or in his absence the President of
Council, shall take the chair at the hour appointed for the meeting, and shall
immediately call Council to order.
   (c)    Roll Call.  The Clerk shall call the roll of the members, and the
names of those present shall be entered in the minutes. 
(Ord. 2-1962.  Passed 6-12-62.)
   (d)    Quorum.  Three members of Council shall constitute a quorum to do
business but a lesser number may adjourn. 
(Ord. 62-2014.  Passed 8-28-14.)
   (e)    Order of Business.  All meetings of Council shall be open to the
public. Promptly at the hour set by law on the day of each regular meeting, the
members of Council, the Mayor, the Clerk and the Law Director shall take their
regular stations in Council Chambers, and the business of Council shall be
taken up for consideration and disposition in the following order:
      (1)    Roll call;
      (2)    Approval of minutes of previous meeting;
      (3)    Public comment;
      (4)    Introduction and adoption of resolutions and ordinances;
      (5)    Communications;
      (6)    Report of Mayor; officers; boards; commissions; committees;
      (7)    Unfinished business;
      (8)    New business;
      (9)    Miscellaneous;
      (10)   Adjournment.
(Ord. 88-2010.  Passed 10-28-10.)
   (f)    Reading of Minutes.  Unless a reading of the minutes of a Council
meeting is requested by a member of Council, such minutes may be approved
without reading if the Clerk has previously furnished each member with a
synopsis thereof.
   (g)    Receiving Motion When Question is Before Council.  When a question or
a proposition is before Council or under debate, or when a motion has been
made, no motions shall be received except the following:
      (1)    To adjourn (not debatable);
      (2)    To table the motion (not debatable);
      (3)    To request that discussion end, and that any motion being
considered be voted on (not debatable);
      (4)    To postpone any action on a motion until some stated future time;
      (5)    To refer the proposal to a standing or special committee;
      (6)    To amend the main motion; or
      (7)    To postpone any action for an indefinite time.
   (h)    Motion to Reconsider.  A motion to reconsider a subject that may have
been acted upon favorably must be made before adjournment of that session of
Council. A motion to reconsider any other subject may be made not later than
the next regular meeting after such action was taken. A motion to reconsider
may be made only by any member who voted with the winning or prevailing side. A
motion to reconsider shall be in order at any time except when a motion on some
other subject is standing.
   (i)    (1)    A motion to reconsider, being laid on the table, may be taken
up and acted upon at any time when Council is engaged in the transaction of new
or miscellaneous business.
      (2)    No motion to reconsider shall be made more than once on any matter
or subject, and the same number of votes shall be required to reconsider the
action of Council, as was required to pass or adopt the same.
   (j)    Motion to Take From the Table.  A motion to take from the table shall
be in order when that order of business is being transacted in which such
matter to be taken up was laid upon the table, or under the head of new or
miscellaneous business, and such motion shall be decided without debate,
provided that the mover may be permitted to state briefly his reasons for the
motion.
   (k)    Motion to Postpone Indefinitely.  If a motion to postpone
indefinitely be carried, the principal question shall be declared lost.
   (l)    Motion for the Previous Question.
      (1)    The previous question shall be in the form, "Shall the main
question now be put?" It shall be admitted only when demanded by two members,
and  until decided shall preclude further debate, and all amendments and
motions. If the previous question is demanded on an amendment, it shall apply
only to the amendment. If the motion for the previous question is carried, the
question shall be put without further debate.
      (2)    If the motion for the previous question is carried, but before it
is actually put in execution, the motion to which it is directed may be laid on
the table.
      (3)    The requirement that two members must be in favor of a motion for
the previous question may be altered, as desired by Council. The reason for
requiring that more than one member be in favor of the motion, before it is
submitted for vote is that consideration and discussion of a question should
not be stopped by only one member. Of course, the motion for the previous
question may be defeated, but that consumes additional time. If more than one
member is in favor of the motion for the previous question, there is then more
reason for submitting the motion to the members for action.
   (m)    Motion to Amend.  A motion to amend is susceptible of but one
amendment thereof. An amendment once rejected may not be moved again in the
same form.
   (n)    Motion on Question of Privilege.  Questions of privilege shall be,
first: Those affecting the rights of Council collectively, its safety, dignity,
and the integrity of its proceedings; second: The rights, reputation and
conduct of the members of Council individually, in their capacity as such
members. A question of privilege shall have precedence of all questions except
a motion to adjourn.
   (o)    Special Committees.  All special committees shall be appointed by the
presiding officer, unless otherwise directed by Council.  (Ord. 2-1962.  Passed
6-12-62.)
   (p)    Standing Committees.  The standing committees of Council shall be:
      (1)    Committee of the Whole;
      (2)    Finance;
      (3)    Public Works (Sewers and Drains);
      (4)   Planning and Zoning;
      (5)    Streets and Highways;
      (6)    Safety (Police and Fire Departments);
      (7)    Utilities;
      (8)    Drainage and Sewer Control Committee;
      (9)   Cemetery Board; and
      (10)   Fire Dependency Board.
   The Council with input from the Mayor shall appoint the chairman for each
committee.  This section applies to representatives to Committees appointed by
Council and not to representatives to Committees appointed by the Mayor.  The
rules of proceedings of the Council shall be observed in the Committee of the
Whole as far as the same may be applicable.
(Ord. 10-2008.  Passed 2-14-08.)
   (q)    Suspension of Rules Relating to Reading Resolutions and Ordinances.
Resolutions and ordinances of a general or permanent nature shall be fully read
on three different days, unless the rules are dispensed with, upon the
affirmative vote of four of the members. The vote on such suspension shall be
taken by yeas and nays, separately on each resolution or ordinance, and the
Clerk shall enter such vote on the minute book, together with the names of
members voting yea and those voting nay.
(Ord. 62-2014.  Passed 8-28-14.)
   (r)    Abstention Votes.  A member of Council who desires not to vote on an
issue before Council, because of conflict of interest or for any reason
whatsoever, shall be entitled to enter an "abstention" vote, which indicates
the member's desire to abstain from any vote on the issue. Should it be
necessary procedurally to count the abstention vote as an affirmative or
negative vote, such vote shall be counted with the majority side of the issue.
However, in the Minutes and for all other purposes, the vote of the member
shall be listed as an "abstention". (Ord. 74-1991. Passed 9-26-91.)
   (s)   Videotaping Council Meetings.  The following rules shall apply to the
videotaping of Council Meetings:
      (1)   Videotaping equipment must be silent, unobtrusive and must not
project any light.
      (2)   All videotaping must take place at the rear of Council chambers on
a platform supplied by the City, and located in such a fashion as to not
interfere with the view of other audience members, nor interfere with the
official videotaping of such meetings.
      (3)   Work sessions of Council may be video taped but due to the limited
space for public observation the use of video recorders may only be done by use
of a tripod situated in the space designated by the Clerk of Council.  (Ord.
10-2013.  Passed 2-28-13.)
   121.03  ASSISTANT CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   There is hereby created the position of Assistant Clerk of Council. The
Assistant Clerk of Council shall perform all of the duties of the Clerk of
Council in the absence of the Clerk of Council and shall perform such other
duties as may be assigned by the Clerk of Council.
(Res. 97-1979. Passed 9-13-79.)
   121.04  ROBERTS' RULES OF ORDER.
   The Council of the City hereby adopts the most current published edition of
Roberts' Rules of Order as and for its rules and regulations for the governing
of its meetings in all circumstances where Council has not adopted a specific
rule or regulation pertinent thereto. (Ord. 74-1991. Passed 9-26-91.)
   121.05 USE OF INTERNET AUCTIONS TO DISPOSE OF CITY PROPERTY.
   (a)   The City may dispose of personal property which is not needed for
public use or is obsolete or unfit for the use for which it was acquired, by
Internet auction.
   (b)   The department head having responsibility for said personal property
shall determine whether the item is of such character and/or value that it
would be more beneficial to the City to place the item for sale via Internet
auction.
   (c)   Bidding shall be open for a minimum of fifteen days and the City shall
determine who will conduct the auction and establish the general terms and
conditions of sale on a case by case basis.
   (d)   Upon adoption of this legislation, the Clerk shall publish in a
newspaper of general circulation in the City, notice of its intent to sell
unneeded, obsolete, or unfit municipal property by Internet auction.  The
notice shall include a summary of the information contained herein and shall be
published at least twice.  A similar notice shall be posted continually
throughout the calendar year in a conspicuous place at City Hall and on the
City’s website.
   (e)   A list of items to be sold by Internet auction will be submitted, from
time to time, to Council for approval.
(Ord. 17-2010.  Passed 2-25-10.)

   123.01  NOTICE OF ENACTMENT OF LEGISLATION.
   (a)    The Clerk shall give public notice of the enactment of the ordinances
and resolutions of Council by posting the same at a conspicuous place in City
Hall, at a location open to the public.
   (b)    Each ordinance and/or resolution shall be posted for a period of not
less than thirty days, and shall be posted within one week after its enactment
by Council and effective date pursuant to the provisions of the Charter.
(Ord. 8-1979. Passed 1-11-79.)
   123.02  READING OF LEGISLATION.
   (a)    All ordinances and resolutions brought before Council for
consideration shall be read in accordance with the provisions of Section
4.09 of the Charter.
   (b)   All legislation to be considered going forward as of the approval date
of this ordinance including and all ordinances and/or resolutions presented to
the Council of the City of Macedonia shall include:
      (1)   The name of the individual originating such legislation
(Originator/Author).
      (2)   The name of a Councilor sponsoring such legislation (Council/
Sponsor).
   Legislation which cannot be traced to an originator and not sponsored by a
Council Member will not be considered by Council and the Clerk of Council will
not allow such items to be brought before Council for consideration.
   
   (c)    Where the Charter is silent, State law shall prevail.
(Ord. 99-2012.  Passed 1-24-13.)
   123.03  NOTICE OF LEGISLATION.
   Any legislation, resolutions or ordinances of a general or permanent nature,
which are to be considered by Council at any regular or special meeting, shall
be presented to each Council member by placing same in their mailbox at City
Hall and/or sent to their City e-mail address no later than forty-eight hours
prior to the scheduled time of the regular or special meeting at which such
legislation is to be considered. This rule may be dispensed with upon a vote of
four of the members of Council. The vote on such suspension may be taken
separately or in conjunction with the suspension of the rules relating to three
readings, and shall be taken by yeas and nays, separately on each piece of
legislation, and the Clerk shall enter such vote on the Minute Book, together
with the names of members voting yea and those voting nay.
(Ord. 62-2014.  Passed 8-28-14.)

   131.01  HOUSING OFFICER.
   The Mayor is hereby designated as the Housing Officer pursuant to Ohio R.C.
3735.66 et seq. for the administration of the Community Reinvestment Areas.
(Res. 98-1988.  Passed 10-27-88.)
   131.02  COLLECTION CONTRACTS.
   (a)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to enter into agreements with
collection agencies to provide for the collection of delinquent fees and costs
owed to the City of Macedonia as is authorized and assessed by any section of
this Code.
   (b)   The referral of these delinquent debts to the authorized collection
agencies with all costs assessed to the debtor is hereby specifically approved
by the Director of Law.
   (c)   A collection services fee is hereby established of up to thirty-three
and one-third percent (33 1/3%) of the balance to be assessed to past due fees,
costs and debts due to the City of Macedonia which are turned over to a
collection agency pursuant to this section.
(Ord. 36-2007.  Passed 4-26-07.)
   131.03  PUBLIC RECORDS POLICY.
   The Mayor is hereby and herein authorized to adopt the Public Records Policy
of the City of Macedonia as attached hereto and incorporated in Ordinance 104-
2007 as an Exhibit and as it may be amended from time to time as deemed
necessary or by reason of future changes in the law and to take all other
actions necessary as it relates to the Public Records Policy of the City of
Macedonia to establish compliance with H.B. 9.
(Ord. 104-2007.  Passed 10-25-07.)

Art. XV
   135.01  DEPUTY DIRECTOR OF FINANCE.
   (a)    There is hereby created the position of Deputy Director of Finance.
   (b)    The Deputy Director of Finance shall perform all such duties as are
provided in Section
6.06 of the Charter.
   (c)    The Deputy Director of Finance shall be paid such compensation as is
fixed by Council.
   (d)    The Deputy Director of Finance shall serve for such period as is
determined by the Mayor. (Ord. 6-1972. Passed 1-13-72.)
   135.02  FINANCE DEPARTMENT CLERK.
   There is hereby created the position of Finance Department Clerk. The
Finance Department Clerk shall work under the supervision of the Director of
Finance, and shall perform such clerical duties in the Finance Department as
are assigned by the Director of Finance. The Finance Department Clerk shall be
paid such compensation as fixed by Council. (Ord. 8-1980. Passed 2-14-80. )
   135.03  BID OPENING BY REVERSE INTERNET AUCTION.
   If the City is required by law to purchase services or supplies by
competitive sealed bidding and the City determines that the use of a reverse
internet auction is advantageous to the political subdivision, the political
subdivision, in accordance with the Ohio Revised Code and any rules and
ordinances which the City adopts, may purchase services or supplies by reverse
internet auction.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, written or oral notice of any extension
shall be given no later than forty-eight hours prior to the original time and
date fixed for the opening to all persons who have received or requested
specifications.  Any modification of the plans or specifications and estimates
of cost for the project for which bids are solicited shall be issued and mailed
or otherwise furnished to persons who have obtained or requested plans or
specifications for the project.  If any modification of the plans or
specifications and estimates of cost for the project is issued seventy-two
hours or less prior to the published time for the opening of bids excluding
Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, the time for opening of bids shall be
extended one week.  Any notice or modification required by this section may be
made by posting the notice or modification on the internet site of the reverse
auction and only if the bid documents announce that such notices and
modifications will be so posted.
   No further advertising of bids is required under this section.  Any notice
required herein may be accomplished by facsimile transmission.  Notice shall be
complete upon mailing or transmission.  (Ord. 4-2008.  Passed 1-24-08.)
   135.04  SPECIAL ASSESSMENT RECORD SEARCH FEE.
   Title or escrow companies requesting that the City perform a search on real
property regarding outstanding fees and charges prior to or commensurate with
the sale of that property shall be assessed a Special Assessment Records Search
Fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per search.  (Ord. 96-2008.  Passed 10-23-08.)
   135.05  SERVICE FEES FOR CITY POLICE AND FIRE SERVICE AT MOTOR VEHICLE
ACCIDENTS.
   (a)   The City shall initiate service fees for the delivery of City Police
and Fire services, personnel, supplies and equipment to the scene of motor
vehicle accidents.  The rate of the service fees shall be that which is the
usual, customary and reasonable costs (UCR), which includes any services,
personnel, supplies and equipment and may vary based on the actual costs of the
individual accident.
   (b)   The service fees shall be charged to the responsible or “at-fault”
driver, initially filed to their motor vehicle insurance, representing an add-
on-cost of the claim for negligent driving damages to the vehicles, property
and/or injuries.  The claim costs shall be filed to the insurance company, the
owner of a vehicle, owner of property, or other responsible parties.
   (c)   The Mayor and/or Chief of Fire and Chief of Police may make rules or
regulations, and from time to time may amend, revoke or add rules and
regulations, relating to this section as they may deem necessary or expedient
in respect to billing for these fees or the collection thereof.
   (d)   All amounts collected as a result of this section shall be placed into
the General Fund of either the Fire Department or the Police Department equal
to each respective department’s involvement, if any, in each motor vehicle
accident for which services were rendered by either or both Departments.  (Ord.
48-2010.  Passed 5-27-10.)
   135.06  CERTIFICATION OF DELINQUENT ASSESSMENT FEES TO SUMMIT COUNTY AND
ESTABLISHING THE AUTHORITY OF THE DIRECTOR OF FINANCE TO USE VARIOUS REMEDIES
FOR COLLECTION.
   In the event any fee assessed on a property owner by any section of the
Codified Ordinances is not paid by the responsible owner within thirty (30)
days of the mailing/delivery of an invoice by the City of Macedonia to either
the owner or his or her designee, that amount is deemed delinquent and may be
forwarded by the Director of Finance to Summit County for placement on the tax
duplicate of the subject property and/or placed into collection and/or
forwarded to the Department of Law for civil suit.  This Authority is granted
to the Director of Finance for all assessed fees except criminal fees issued by
the Mayor’s Court.  In addition to the original amount of the assessment due
and owing, the delinquent owner shall also be responsible for any costs
incurred by the City for the placement of the delinquency on the tax duplicate
and/or the cost of collection and/or costs of the civil suit.
(Ord. 40-2013.  Passed 3-28-13.)
   135.07  CREDIT CARD POLICY.
   Council hereby adopts the Credit Card Policy attached to Ordinance 5-2019 as
Exhibit A and incorporated herein by reference to govern the use of City of
Macedonia credit card accounts as set forth therein, which Policy may be
amended from time to time by the City.
(Ord. 5-2019.  Passed 1-24-19.)
CHAPTER 137
Department of Public Service
137.01   Assistant Director of Public Service
CROSS REFERENCES

   139.01  LIABILITY FOR HAZARDOUS WASTE INCIDENTS.
   In the event of a hazardous materials incident, as described in 49 Code of
Federal Regulations 171.16, which is incorporated by reference herein,
requiring the response of the Fire Department and/or others in the service of
the City to control such incident and/or clean and dispose of the material and
equipment, the transporter (carrier, trucking company, etc.) shall be liable to
the City for the payment of all costs and expenses of the Fire Department and/
or others incurred in and about the use of employees, apparatus and materials
in the control and/or neutralization of and/or clean up and disposal from the
incident. The amount of such costs and expenses shall be determined by the
Director of Public Safety and shall be collected by him in a civil action
wherein the City shall be plaintiff and the transporter shall be defendant.
This responsibility is not conditioned upon evidence of willfulness or
negligence on the part of the transporter.
(Ord. 27-1986. Passed 5-22-86.)
   139.02  ADVANCE PAYMENT FOR SAFETY FORCE MEMBERS DEPLOYED  TO NATURAL
DISASTERS OR MATTERS OF HOMELAND SECURITY.
   In the event a federal, state or county agency deploys members of the City’s
safety forces for natural disasters response or matters of Homeland Security,
the City shall continue to pay the members at their regular hourly rate for all
regular hours and time and one-half time their regular rate for all overtime
hours, including Chiefs and other salaried executive officers, on the condition
of full reimbursement from the appropriate federal, state or county agency.
(Ord. 88-2008.  Passed 9-11-08.)

CHAPTER 145
Civil Service Commission
145.01   Commission established.
145.02   Membership.

CROSS REFERENCES
      Civil Service - see Ohio Constitution, Art. XV, Sec. 10
      Creation and duties - see CHTR.

      Application of Civil Service regulations - see CHTR.

   145.01  COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby created a Civil Service Commission. No appointment,
transfer, promotion, demotion or discharge shall be made of persons in the
classified service after July 1, 1971, except pursuant to the rules of the
Civil Service Commission.
(Ord 23-1971. Passed 3-25-71.)
   145.02  MEMBERSHIP.
   The Civil Service Commission shall consist of five electors of the
Municipality, not holding other Municipal office or appointment, to be
appointed by the Mayor, with the approval of a majority of the members elected
to Council. Each shall serve for a term of six years except that one of the
three electors first appointed shall be designated by the Mayor to serve for a
term of two years and one for a term of four years, all commencing April 1,
1971. A vacancy occurring during the term of any member of the Commission shall
be filled for the unexpired term by the Mayor with the approval of a majority
of the members elected to Council. (Ord. 23-1971. Passed 3-25-71.)
   145.03  OFFICERS.
   The Civil Service Commission shall designate one of its members as chairman
and may appoint a secretary who need not be a member of the Commission and may
hold other Municipal office or appointment.  The Commission shall elect
officers at its first meeting of each year, who shall serve in that office
until the end of that year.
(Ord. 55-2014.  Passed 5-22-14.)
   145.04  CLASSIFICATION OF SERVICE.
   The Civil Service of the Municipality is hereby divided into the
unclassified and the classified service.
   (a)    The unclassified service shall include:
      (1)    All officers elected by the people;
      (2)    All directors of departments excluding the Chief of Police and
Fire Chief.
      (3)    The members of all boards or commissions appointed by the Mayor;
      (4)    All officers and employees appointed by Council;
      (5)    Unskilled labor;
      (6)    All part-time employees;
      (7)    All secretarial and clerical help; and
      (8)    All maintenance department employees.
   (b)    The classified service shall include all full-time police officers
and all full-time firemen including the Chief of Police and the Fire Chief,
when employed full- time.
      (Ord. 38-1971. Passed 9-23-71.)
   145.05  DUTIES.
   The Civil Service Commission shall provide by rule for ascertainment of
merit and fitness as the basis for appointment and promotion in the classified
service of the Municipality as required by the Constitution of the State, and
for appeals from the action of the Mayor or other administrative officials in
case of transfer, reduction or removal except as otherwise provided in State
statutes or the ordinances of Council. The action of the Commission on any
appeal shall be final except for appeal to the Common Pleas Court. The
Commission shall keep a record of its proceedings.
(Ord. 23-1971. Passed 3-25-71.)
   145.06  COMPENSATION AND FUNDS.
   Members of the Civil Service Commission shall serve without compensation
unless  otherwise provided by ordinance. A sufficient sum shall be appropriated
by Council to carry out the civil service provisions of this ordinance or
amendments thereto.
(Ord. 23-1971. Passed 3-25-71.)
   145.07  REMOVAL.
   The Mayor may at any time suspend any Civil Service Commissioners for
inefficiency, neglect of duty, misfeasance, nonfeasance or malfeasance in
office, incapacity or incompetency, having first given to such Commissioner a
copy of the charges setting forth the specific charges against him. An
opportunity shall be given such Commissioner to be publicly heard before
Council, in person or by counsel in his defense, present evidence, or examine
any witness appearing in support of such charge. Only upon the affirmative vote
of the majority of the members elected to Council hearing such charges shall
such Commissioner be removed from office, but in no event shall Council hear
such charges unless there be a quorum present.
(Ord. 23-1971. Passed 3-25-71.)
CHAPTER 146
Volunteers and Volunteer Organizations
146.01   Purpose.
146.02   Volunteers.
146.03   Volunteer organizations.
146.04   Council powers.
   146.01  PURPOSE.
   (a)   Citizens and organized volunteer groups desire on occasion to
contribute their time, energy and/or resources to the City of Macedonia to an
individual program or particular department.  The purpose of this Chapter is to
establish standards to those individuals and organized groups so as to utilize
their good intentions in the best manner possible while at the same time
protecting those individuals and groups as well as the health, safety and
welfare of the citizens and employees and assets of the City of Macedonia.  It
should never be thought that the purpose of this Chapter is to impair or
inhibit the generosity of our citizenry, but rather to channel and direct it
for the most productive result.
   (b)   This Chapter doesn’t apply to coaches, assistants, or other volunteers
who are under the authority or direct control of any City run program or
activity.
(Ord. 34-2002.  Passed 7-11-02.)
   146.02  VOLUNTEERS.
   (a)   Any volunteer individuals shall be directed when possible to already
existing volunteer organizations or groups which have been approved by the City
of Macedonia per this Chapter, and are already operating in the same or similar
capacity.  Such individuals will be recommended to the existing group and
considered by them for inclusion in their activities.  If no existing
organization is available, the individuals may be approved upon the
recommendation of the Mayor, and approval of Council, as provided for, and
under the same criteria as set forth in Section
146.03.
   (b)   Individual volunteers shall be required to sign waivers of liability,
and assume the risk of their activity on behalf of the City.  Such individuals
shall be prohibited from indicating that they are ever acting on behalf of the
City, and shall also be prohibited from soliciting funds on behalf of the City,
unless expressly authorized by an organization approved by the City to do so,
or approved by the Mayor and Council to do so.
   (c)   No individual volunteers shall be permitted to operate City equipment
without the express permission of the department head overseeing such
equipment, and shall not be permitted to have keys to any City property or
equipment except for a specific purpose and a limited time as approved by the
department overseeing such property.
(Ord. 34-2002.  Passed 7-11-02.)
   146.03  VOLUNTEER ORGANIZATIONS.
   (a)   Any volunteer organization, group, or special committee, proposing to
donate time, energy or resources on behalf of any endeavor of the City of
Macedonia, shall be prohibited from acting in such capacity without being
formally approved by the City Council, with the Mayor’s recommendation.  Such
approval will only be granted after compliance and an initial filing of the
following:
      (1)   A structure of the volunteer organization is submitted, indicating
any state or federal organization approvals with supporting documentation as to
profit or nonprofit status.  Such structure shall include a roster of all
executive officers, their addresses and telephone numbers, and shall be updated
annually after approval, and be filed with the office of the Mayor.
      (2)   That any financial needs or goals of the organization shall be
clearly established in the form of a plan, including the origin of any
resources to be used, and any City equipment, property or employees anticipated
to be requested, and be filed with the office of the Mayor.
      (3)   A detailed project plan will be provided which identifies the focus
or the goal of the organization, including an implementation and termination
date, and shall be filed with office of the Mayor.
      (4)   Any formal recognition by IRS or State authorities shall be
maintained in a current status, as well as any insurance coverage obtained or
applicable to such organization, and shall be filed with the office of the
Mayor.
      (5)   In addition to the initial filing requirements set forth in
subparagraphs (1), (2), (3) and (4) hereof, each approved volunteer
organization shall file an annual report with the office of the Mayor on or
before January 31 of each year setting forth any amendments or changes in the
volunteer organizations from the time of the initial filing.
   (b)   Volunteer organizations shall be approved initially by Council with
the Mayor’s recommendation.
   (c)   No volunteer organization shall have the ability to raise funds or
solicit donations except with the approval of Council or as outlined in their
proposal approved under Subparagraph (a) hereof.
   (d)   All volunteer organizations approved and operating within the City
shall provide an annual accounting of all funds solicited, raised and spent to
be filed with the office of the Mayor on or before January 31 of each year.
   (e)   Each volunteer organization will acknowledge that any municipal
property or assets used or improved by them shall be the ultimate
responsibility of the City of Macedonia, and such organizations shall be
required to surrender such property or to remove themselves from such property
upon notice from the City.
   (f)   No volunteer organization shall have keys to any City property except
for a limited purpose and for a defined limited period of time as outlined in
their proposal approved under Paragraph (a) hereof.  Any such release of keys
shall be documented by signed receipt dated and on file in the office of the
Mayor.
   (g)   Each approved volunteer organization within the City shall have a
designated City representative, approved by the Mayor and a majority of
Council, who will be the liaison between such organization and the Council as a
whole.
(Ord. 34-2002.  Passed 7-11-02.)
   146.04  COUNCIL POWERS.
   Council retains unto itself the sole and exclusive authority to suspend,
terminate, or rescind any approved volunteer organization’s right to operate,
volunteer, or function within the City of Macedonia, on City property, or on
behalf of the City itself.  Council shall be the sole determining factor as to
the termination or suspension of any organization, and no grounds or cause need
be established to do so.  (Ord. 34-2002.  Passed 7-11-02.)

147.01   Established.

CROSS REFERENCES
      Bonds for recreational facilities - see Ohio R.C. 133.032, 755.17
      Power to construct recreational centers - see Ohio R.C. 717.01

13.01
   147.01  ESTABLISHED.
   In accordance with Section
13.01 of the Charter, the Parks and Recreation Board (Ordinance 21-1984) shall
be the Parks and Recreation Commission, which shall serve as a public agency of
the City.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.02  MEMBERS; TERM; REMOVAL.
   (a)    The Parks and Recreation Commission shall consist of six electors of
the Municipality, not holding other municipal office, who shall be appointed by
the Mayor, and confirmed by the majority of the members elected to Council, and
shall be composed initially of the members of the Parks and Recreation Board
whose terms shall continue.
   (b)    Each member of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall serve for a
term of five years, which shall continue consecutively from those first
appointed to the Parks and Recreation Board, where the terms of those first
appointed expired on the dates indicated below:
      (1)    January 1, 1979;
      (2)    January 1, 1980;
      (3)    January 1, 1981;
      (4)    January 1, 1982;
      (5)    January 1, 1983;
      (6)    January 1, 1989.  (Ord. 109-1989.  Passed 12-14-89.)
   (c)    Any member of the Parks and Recreation Commission can be removed by
the Mayor if a majority of the members elected to Council approve such removal
by a vote at a regularly scheduled meeting of Council. Any member of the Parks
and Recreation Commission can be removed by Council by a  two-thirds
affirmative vote of the members elected to Council.  (Ord. 94-2018.  Passed 9-
13-18.)
   (d)    The Commission shall include one member of Council elected by Council
annually. Such member has the right to vote.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.03  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Parks and Recreation Commission shall serve in an advisory capacity to
develop plans to equip and operate playgrounds, gymnasiums, swimming pools,
recreation centers and parks and conservation land. The Commission shall assist
the Director in the operation of the Parks and Recreation Department. The
Commission, with the aid of the Director, shall draft and approve a line item
budget which shall be presented to Council in a meeting at an appointed date.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.04  OFFICERS.
   At its first meeting in any year, the Parks and Recreation Commission shall
elect a chairman and vice-chairman and select all other necessary officers to
serve for a period extending throughout that year, and may employ such other
persons as are needed. The Commission shall adopt rules and regulations for the
conduct of all of the business within its jurisdiction. The Director of Parks
and Recreation shall act as Commission secretary and shall be a non-voting
member of the Commission. The officers, rules and employees of the Parks and
Recreation Board shall continue for the Commission until changed.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.05  EXPENSES.
   All expenses incurred in the operation of the parks and recreational
facilities shall be charged to the various line items of the approved budget by
approval of the Parks and Recreation Commission. Any expenditures not in the
approved line item budget must have approval (so funds can be obtained) of
Council prior to any commitments for such expenditures.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.06  COMPENSATION.
   The members of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall serve without
compensation. (Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.07  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Parks and Recreation Commission shall adopt its own rules and
regulations. The rules and regulations shall be submitted to Council for their
concurrence.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.08  DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION.
   (a)    There shall be, and there is hereby, the position of Director of
Parks and Recreation, who shall be the head of the Parks and Recreation
Department and shall serve under the general supervision of the Mayor, on the
advise of the Parks and Recreation Commission and subject to confirmation of
the majority of the members elected to Council.
   (b)    The Director of Parks and Recreation shall have knowledge of
municipal park and recreation operations, budgetary and supervision skills. The
Director of Parks and Recreation shall serve until removal as provided herein,
or upon written resignation.
   (c)    The Director of Parks and Recreation shall, under general supervision
of the Mayor, supervise the Parks and Recreation Department and shall manage,
conduct, and supervise all operations of Municipal parks and recreation areas
and facilities.
   (d)    The Director of Parks and Recreation may be removed by the Mayor, if
a majority of the members elected to Council approve such removal, by a vote at
a regularly scheduled meeting of Council. The Director of Parks and Recreation
may be removed by Council by a three-fourths affirmative vote of the members
elected to Council.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.09  PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT.
   There shall be, and there hereby is, a Parks and Recreation Department,
which shall include the Director and such other employees as Council shall
provide. Such employees shall work under the general supervision of the
Director and shall be appointed by the Mayor, with confirmation by the majority
of the members elected to Council.
(Ord. 109-1989. Passed 12-14-89.)
   147.10  SENIOR CITIZEN DISCOUNTS FOR PARKS AND RECREATION PROGRAMS.
   All residents of the City, sixty-two years of age and older, shall be
entitled to a fifty percent (50%) discount on selected programs offered by the
Macedonia Parks and Recreation Department.
(Ord. 75-1991. Passed 8-22-91.)
   147.11  PERMITTED USES FOR THE MACEDONIA PARK AND RECREATION TRUST FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created a “Macedonia Park and Recreation Trust Fund”
and that the Director of Finance shall maintain such fund for and on behalf of
the City of Macedonia as a repository for funds gained from the lease of park
property to 2Club Golf of Macedonia, LLC, or any subsequently approved assignee
thereof, in Longwood Park and for various contributions related to such
facility.
   (b)   The Director of Finance shall as soon as possible submit to the Mayor,
the Parks and Recreation Director and the Parks and Recreation Commission the
amount anticipated to be available from 2Club Golf of Macedonia LLC, during the
fiscal year of 2005.
   (c)   Council shall meet annually in January, to approve the plan for
spending the money based on the recommendation of the Parks and Recreation
Director and the Parks and Recreation Commission.  All expenditures from this
trust fund shall be approved by the affirmative vote of the members elected to
Council through resolution.
   (d)   Council may re-evaluate the fund at any time and make changes in
spending or procedures for use of the fund, but any changes must be approved by
the affirmative vote of the members elected to Council through written
resolution of Council.
(Res. 88-2004.  Passed 1-13-05.)
   147.12  RECREATION FEE DISCOUNTS FOR MEMBERS OF BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS.
   All members of the various boards and commissions established within the
Charter of the City and those listed in the City of Macedonia Directory Guide
after one year of serving on said board or commission and thereafter for so
long as they hold such office, shall be entitled to receive recreation fee
discounts to the Family Recreation Center in the same amounts, description and
with the same requirements as those provided City employees in the approved
plan dated January 22, 2004. 
(Res. 8-2012.  Passed 3-22-12.)
CHAPTER 148
Land Conservancy
148.01   Established.
148.02   Land Conservancy Board.
   148.01  ESTABLISHED.
   There is established within the City of Macedonia a Macedonia Land
Conservancy for the purposes of acquiring vacant land to be preserved as open
space and/or for park purposes.
(Ord. 60-1999.  Passed 8-12-99.)
   148.02  LAND CONSERVANCY BOARD.
   (a)   The Land Conservancy will be controlled by the Land Conservancy Board
comprised of the Mayor, President of Council and three resident land owners who
are appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council.
   (b)   Civilian Board members will serve a three (3) year term in the
interest of seeking out the acquisition of vacant land which is most beneficial
for the City.  All recommendations from the Macedonia Land Conservancy Board
will be made to the Planning Commission for review and recommendation to the
City Council who will have final approval for the acquisition of such vacant
land.  (Ord. 60-1999.  Passed 8-12-99.)

CHAPTER 151
Police Department
151.01   Composition.
151.02   Police dispatcher.
151.03   Appointment.
151.04   Injury leave.
151.05   Protection outside City limits.
151.06   Conditions of employment for part-time police officers.
151.07   Fingerprinting services.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Assistance of State Criminal Bureau - see Ohio R.C. 109.51 et seq.
      Peace officer training certificate required for permanent employment -
see Ohio R.C. 109.77
      Probationary period; age - see Ohio R.C. 124.27, 124.30, 124.41
      Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 742
      Police officer may arrest on view - see Ohio R.C. 2935.03, 2935.05,
2935.07
      Charter provisions - see CHTR.
8.04
      Civil service - see ADM. Ch.
145
   151.01  COMPOSITION.
   (a)   The Police Department shall consist of the Chief of Police and such
officers and employees as may be provided for by Council.  The Chief of the
Police Department shall be in immediate charge of the Department, and shall
have control over the stationing and transfer of all police officers and other
employees constituting the Police Department along with all other powers
prescribed by law.
   (b)   In addition to the Chief of Police, the members of the regular Police
Department shall consist of the following:
      (1)   Lieutenant who shall serve as the Executive Assistant to the Chief
of Police and in the absence of the Chief, exercise the authority and perform
the duties of the Chief.
      (2)   Any number up to five Sergeants.
      (3)   Such number of regular, full-time police officers as may be
provided for by Council.
      (4)   Secretary to the Police Chief, who shall be full-time and
nonclassified, and who shall serve as a confidential employee and assigned
duties and responsibilities by the Chief of the Department.
   (c)   The part-time members of the Police Department may consist of 15 part-
time police officers.  (Ord. 79-1997.  Passed 12-11-97; Ord. 41-2003.  Passed
8-28-03.)
   151.02  POLICE DISPATCHER.
   There shall be such number of police dispatchers as may be provided for by
Council, with duties as shall be assigned by the Chief of Police and/or
Director of Safety.
(Ord. 79-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   151.03  APPOINTMENT.
   Appointment of regular police officers and police dispatchers shall be made
according to Section
8.04 of the City Charter.
(Ord. 79-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   151.04  INJURY LEAVE.
   Any regular full-time employee of the Police Department injured or
incapacitated in the actual discharge of duty who is compelled to be absent
from duty as a result of such injury, shall, upon recommendation of a certified
physician and Council, receive full pay for such time as may be deemed
equitable by Council.  However, deduction may be made to the extent of the sums
received by the employee from and such compensation fund to which the state,
county or City contributes.  This section shall be superseded by any collective
bargaining provision addressing the leave.  (Ord. 79-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   151.05  PROTECTION OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS.
   (a)   The Police Chief is empowered to authorize the Police Department to
provide police protection to any county, municipal corporation or township of
this state or to government entity of an adjoining state without contract where
appropriate.
   (b)   It is specially intended that all of the rights, privilege,
indemnifications of applicable Ohio law including, but not limited to, the
provisions of Ohio Chapter 2744 shall be extended to officers of the City
Police Department who take any action under the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 79-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   151.06  CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT FOR PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS.
   Part-time police officers shall be not less than twenty-one years of age. 
Candidates for appointment may be required to undergo a medical, psychological
and polygraph examination and physical agility testing as may be prescribed by
the Police Chief and/or Director of Safety.
(Ord. 79-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   151.07  FINGERPRINTING SERVICES.
   The Police Department, as administered by the Chief of Police, may provide
fingerprinting services to any resident, any person employed in the City, or to
any company, business, school or organization located in the City for a fee. 
The amount of the fee shall be set by the Chief of Police with the approval of
the Mayor.
(Ord. 11-2006.  Passed 2-9-06.)
CHAPTER 153
Fire Department
153.01   Composition.
153.02   Volunteer Fire Fighter's Dependents' Fund and Board.
153.03   Conditions of employment for part-time fire fighters.
153.04   Probationary service.
153.05   Aid of other communities.
153.06   Charges for emergency rescue squad service.
153.07   Fees to be charged to the party responsible for a motor vehicle
collision or incident.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 146
      Fire protection contracts - see Ohio R.C. 307.05, 505.44, 717.02
      Schooling, buildings and equipment - see Ohio R.C. 715.05, 737.23 et seq.
      Gas masks for firemen; requirements - see Ohio R.C. 3737.31
      Composition, appointment - see CHTR.
8.05
   153.01  COMPOSITION.
   In addition to the Fire Chief, the Fire Department may consist of the
following:
   (a)   Assistant Fire Chief, who shall serve as the Executive Assistant to
the Fire Chief, who, in the absence of the Chief, is authorized to exercise the
authority and perform the duties of the Chief; (Ord.  55-2019.  Passed 7-11-
19.)
   (b)   Any number of up to three Fire Lieutenants;
   (c)   Any number of regular, full-time fire fighters as may be provided for
by Council;
   (d)   Any number of part-time fire fighters as may be provided for by
Council who shall be appointed pursuant to Section
8.05(b) of the Charter.  All part-time fire fighters shall be considered
"0regular firemen" for the purpose of workers' compensation and insurance
coverage and benefits.  Part-time fire fighters may be assigned certain ranks
and designated duties pursuant to the Macedonia Fire Department's Standard
Operating Procedure Manual.
   (e)   Secretary to the Fire Chief, a nonclassified position, who shall serve
as a confidential employee and assigned duties and responsibilities by the
Chief of the Department.
      (Ord. 80-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   153.02  VOLUNTEER FIRE FIGHTER'S DEPENDENTS' FUND AND BOARD.
   Under the provision of Ohio R.C. Chapter 146, there is established a
volunteer fire fighters' dependents' fund to be administered by a Volunteer
Fire Fighter's Dependent Board which shall be composed of and have such powers
as are set forth in Ohio R.C. Chapter 146.
(Ord. 80-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   153.03  CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT FOR PART-TIME FIRE FIGHTERS.
   Part-time fire fighters shall be not less than eighteen years of age and
must live within a reasonable driving distance to the City as determined by the
Fire Chief.  Candidates for appointment may be required to undergo a medical
and psychological examination and physical agility testing as may be prescribed
by the Fire Chief and/or Director of Safety.  As a condition of appointment,
all part-time fire fighters must hold an EMT (basic) certification from the
State of Ohio.  Appointments to the position of part-time fire fighter shall be
made according to Section
8.05(b) of the Charter.
(Ord.55-1999.  Passed 6-24-99.)
   153.04  PROBATIONARY SERVICE.
   All original appointments made to the position of full-time fire fighter or
part-time fire fighter shall be subject to a probationary period of one year of
continuous service according to the procedures set forth in Section
8.05 of the Charter.
(Ord. 80-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   153.05  AID OF OTHER COMMUNITIES.
   The Fire Chief is authorized to allow the Fire Department to provide fire
protection and/or emergency assistance to other political subdivisions
according to Ohio R.C. 737.10.
(Ord. 80-1997.  Passed 12-11-97.)
   153.06  CHARGES FOR EMERGENCY RESCUE SQUAD SERVICE.
   (a)   The Director of Finance and the Chief of the Fire Department shall
establish the costs incurred in the providing of Rescue Squad services, and
will begin invoicing all users for such services.  For all City residents and
all nonresident Nordonia Hills City School District students while
participating in an authorized school activity within the City, invoicing will
be in the form of a request of an assignment of insurance company proceeds
available to the resident, and will accept as full payment the usual and
customary rates as allowed by the particular insurance company.  The City will
not charge or collect any amount of money in excess of the insurance payments
received and available to the persons described above who receive Rescue Squad
services for the reason that operating revenues received from local taxes, of
all kinds, are being treated as payment of otherwise applicable co-payments and
deductibles.
   (b)   Nonresidents will be invoiced for the entire cost of the rescue squad
services after being credited for any available assignment of insurance company
proceeds.
(Ord. 16-2003.  Passed 3-13-03.)
   153.07  FEES TO BE CHARGED TO THE PARTY RESPONSIBLE FOR A MOTOR VEHICLE
COLLISION OR INCIDENT.
   (a)   The Chief of the Macedonia Fire Department, with the approval of the
Mayor, is authorized and directed to establish a schedule of fees to be charged
to the party responsible for the motor vehicle collision or incident to their
insurance carrier when the Division of Fire responds to the scene of an MVA. 
Fees collected shall be for the services rendered including, but not limited
to, securing the scene of the accident, the establishment of a safety zone, the
extrication of the victims if trapped, providing any fire/medical services and
the extinguishment of vehicle fires, as necessary.
   (b)   Upon establishing the schedule of fees as set forth in subsection (a)
hereof, the Fire Chief is further authorized to begin invoicing all parties
responsible for the MVA or their insurance carriers through the same company
under contract with the City that provides EMS billing.
   (c)   The proceeds from the MVA fire services billing shall be placed into a
special fund that will be used exclusively for Macedonia Fire Department
operations.
(Ord. 79-2004.  Passed 1-13-05.)

   155.03  DUTIES.
   (a)    The Animal Warden shall collect and impound all dogs running at

chickens, fowl and other domestic animals, as well as dogs, excepting cats; and
impound and hold all such animals and fowl; and on notice to the owners,
authorize the sale of such animals and fowl for the failure of owners to pay

animals and/or fowl to run at large is a violation of law.
