CROSS REFERENCES
      Ohio Basic Building Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1301
      CABO One and Two-Family Dwelling Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1309
      Architectural standards - see BLDG. Ch.
1341
      Structures under construction - see BLDG. Ch.
1373
   1365.01  RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)    Owner.  The owner of every human habitation, building, structure or
premises shall be responsible for maintaining it in a clean and sanitary
condition.
   (b)   Occupant.  The occupant of any human habitation, building, structure
or premises also shall be responsible for maintaining in a clean and sanitary
condition that part of the habitation, building, structure or premises which he
occupies and controls.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.02  GENERAL MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    All human habitations, buildings and structures and all parts
thereof, both exterior and interior, shall be maintained in good repair and
shall be capable of performing the function for which such structure or part or
any feature thereof was designed or intended to be used.
   (b)    All equipment and facilities appurtenant to such structures shall be
maintained in good and safe working order.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.03  FOUNDATIONS.
   (a)    All foundations of any human habitation and any building shall be
maintained in structurally sound condition and in good repair.
   (b)    All foundations of any human habitation and any building shall be
maintained in such condition as to prevent seepage or leakage of water into the
space enclosed within such foundations.
   (c)    All openings into the foundations of any human habitation and any
building shall be protected against the entrance of rodents.
   (d)    Where parts of any human habitation and any building supported on
masonry piers require substantial repair or replacement due to sagging,
settling or failure of supporting piers, the same shall be replaced with a
foundation conforming to the Building Code of the City. (Ord. 27-1982. Passed
4-22-82.)
   1365.04  ROOFS, GUTTERS AND DOWNSPOUTS.
   All roofs of any human habitation and any building shall be maintained
weathertight and roof drainage shall be handled by suitable collectors and
downspouts connected to a public storm sewer. Where storm sewer or other storm
drainage outlet is not available, downspouts may discharge onto splash blocks
or other devices, provided that no excess water will flow onto adjoining
property or over sidewalks. Connection of any pipe carrying roof water or yard
drainage to a sanitary sewer is prohibited.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.05  MAINTENANCE OF EXTERIORS.
   (a)    All exterior walls of any human habitation and any building shall be
maintained weathertight and so as to resist decay or deterioration from any
cause.
   (b)    Any human habitation, building or structure whose exterior surface is
bare, deteriorated, ramshackle, tumble-down, decaying, disintegrated or in poor
repair must be repaired or razed.
      (1)    All buckled, rotted or decayed walls, doors, windows, porches,
floors, steps, railings, soffits, posts, sills, trim and their missing members
must be replaced and put in good condition.
      (2)    All replacements must match and conform to original design or be
replaced completely.
      (3)    All exterior wood or exterior unfinished surfaces must be sealed
and painted, or the surface covered with other approved protective coating or
treated to prevent rot and decay and conform to and match the existing paint or
surface covering and original design or replacement thereof. All exterior walls
and surfaces must be properly protected against the weather where such are
defective or lack weather protection, including lack of paint or surface
covering, or have deteriorated due to lack of proper protective covering.
   (c)    Any human habitation, building or structure whose exterior surface is
deteriorated, decaying, disintegrating or whose exterior surface has weathered
with dirt and grime or has been impaired through peeling or flaking of the
paint or other protective coating, shall be repaired, repainted or resurfaced.
      (1)    All exterior surfaces shall be replaced or repaired in good
condition before repainting or coating.
      (2)    All bare exterior surfaces which are flaking or crumbling shall be
replaced or sealed in a good workmanlike manner.
      (3)    All new or repaired bare surfaces shall be painted or coated.
         (Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.06  MAINTENANCE OF INTERIOR WALLS AND FLOORS.
   (a)    All interior walls and floors of any human habitation and any
building shall be maintained free of holes, large cracks and any loose or
deteriorated material.
   (b)    The floors of all bathrooms and water closet compartments shall have
a cove base at walls and partitions. Floor surfaces and cove base shall be of
nonabsorbent materials with moisture-resistant joints.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.07  INFESTATION BY PESTS.
   All premises shall be maintained free from sources of breeding, harborage
and infestation by insects, vermin or rodents.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.08  EXTERIOR PROPERTY AREAS.
   No owner, operator or tenant of any premises shall maintain or permit to be
maintained at or on the exterior property areas of such premises any condition
which deteriorates or debases the appearance of the neighborhood, adversely
alters the appearance and general character of the neighborhood, creates a
fire, safety or health hazard, or which is a public nuisance, including but not
limited to the following:
   (a)    Broken or dilapidated fences, walls or other structures.
   (b)    Broken, uneven or improperly maintained walks or driveways.
   (c)    Out-of-use or nonusable, dilapidated appliances, trailers, motor
vehicles and parts and boats.
   (d)    Rags, rugs or other materials hung on lines or in other places on
such premises, which materials are not being used for general household or
housekeeping purposes; broken, dilapidated or unusable furniture, mattresses or
other household furnishings; plastic materials, paints, miscellaneous coverings
and/or any other materials, including those described in this section placed at
or on the premises in such a manner as to be patently unsightly, grotesque or
offensive to the senses.
   (e)    Lawns, landscaping and driveways shall also be maintained so as not
to constitute a blighting or deteriorating effect in the neighborhood.
   (f)    Except as provided below, vacant lots must be upgraded to prevent
erosion. Vacant lots adjoining habitations shall be seeded and maintained in a
state equivalent to adjoining lots which contain the habitation.
   (g)    Vacant lots which are naturally wooded shall be maintained in a
natural, wooded state. (Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   (h)    Notwithstanding any other provision herein, no exterior area shall be
maintained in violation of Section
909.04 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (Ord. 61-1988. Passed 6-9-88. )
   1365.09  REMOVAL OR REPLACEMENT OF DEFECTIVE CONDITIONS.
   (a)    All structures shall either be maintained in good repair and free
from health, accident and fire hazards or shall be removed from the premises.
   (b)    Where foundations of structures have deteriorated or settled to the
point where wall plates or studs are rotting, they shall be replaced with
foundations as required under the Building Code.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.10  ACCESS AND EGRESS; KEYBOX SYSTEM.
   (a)    Every occupied unit, wherein there is not a common hallway, shall be
provided with direct and approved means of access and egress to the outside
without passing through any part of another unit. In multiple dwellings, any
door which is used in connection with such means of access and egress shall be
provided with a lock which can be opened from the inside without the use of a
key.
   (b)    All newly constructed, nonresidential buildings shall install a high-
security keybox system approved by the Building Commissioner and Fire
Department, which shall be designed to give fire fighters, police and other
emergency services, immediate access to locked buildings, elevators and other
secured areas in case of emergency.  All existing nonresidential buildings
shall comply with this section before December 31, 2001.
(Ord. 25-2000.  Passed 4-27-00.)
   1365.11  HEAT REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    The owner and/or occupant of any structure intended for habitation
shall maintain heat in such structure, whether then occupied or not, in order
to prevent deterioration.
   (b)    Every appliance or piece of equipment burning solid, liquid or
gaseous fuel, where permitted, shall be connected to approved smokepipe and
flue. However, any appliance approved for use without such connections is
exempted from this section. This section shall be applicable to all building
codes in the City.
   (c)    No heating equipment or any appliance depending on room air for
combustion shall be located in any bedroom, bathroom, toilet room or any room
used for sleeping purposes. This section shall be applicable to all building
codes in the City.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.12  ELECTRICAL FACILITIES REQUIRED.
   Every human habitation, building or structure shall be provided with
approved electrical service, outlets and fixtures, which shall be installed and
maintained as to be free of any potential source of ignition of combustible
material or any potential source of electrical hazard. Such facilities shall be
approved as being adequate to supply the requirements of lighting, appliances
and equipment to the structure concerned.  This section shall be applicable to
all building codes in the City.
(Ord. 27-1982. Passed 4-22-82.)
   1365.13  RUBBISH AND GARBAGE DISPOSAL.
   (a)    Every occupant of any structure shall dispose of all his rubbish in a
clean and sanitary manner by placing it in a sanitary receptacle.
   (b)    Every occupant of any structure shall dispose of all his garbage and
other waste which might provide food for insects and rodents, in a clean and
sanitary manner by placing it in approved nonleakable, nonabsorbent, covered
garbage storage receptacles or in other approved garbage disposal facilities.
   (c)    No waste container or other item for disposal shall be placed between
the building setback line and the street before 12:00 p.m. of the day before
pickup, nor left after 7:00 p.m. of the day of the pickup. (Ord. 74-2017. 
Passed 9-14-17.)
   1365.14  ENFORCEMENT AND AUTHORIZED INSPECTION.
   (a)    This chapter shall be enforced by the Building Department and the
Building and Zoning Inspector. Every owner or occupant shall upon written
request permit the Building and Zoning Inspector or any authorized Building
Inspector of the Building Department access to real property upon request
during the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday of each
week, excepting legal holidays, for the purpose of making inspections within or
outside of any building or structure necessary to enforce this chapter. The
failure to allow access to real property within or outside of buildings or
structures for inspection during the period provided for herein and upon
identification of the Inspector(s) shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.
   (b)    The owner of any building, structure or premises, who enters into an
agreement to convey an interest in such building, structure or premises shall
obtain from the Building and Zoning Inspector a Certificate of Exterior
Inspection, pursuant to the requirements of Chapter
1327 of the Codified Ordinances, entitled "Point of Sale Exterior Inspection".
(Ord. 45-1992. Passed 7-23-92.)
   1365.15  NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS.
   (a)    For all provisions of this chapter except subsection
1365.08(h), written notice to the owner or occupant of a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by the Building Commissioner and/or Zoning
Inspector to correct the violation indicated in such notice mailed to the last
known address of the owner or occupant, the owner or occupant of the property
notified of any violation hereunder shall correct violation within thirty (30)
days of the date noted upon such written notice. The failure by the owner or
occupant of such property to correct such violation within the thirty (30) day
period provided for shall be a violation of this chapter.
 
   (b)    Notice of a violation under Section
1365.08(h) shall be as prescribed in Section
909.04(c), and a violation hereunder shall occur for noncompliance after seven
(7) days after such notice is served or published.  (Ord.  37-2019.  Passed 4-
25-19.)
   (c)    In the event that any Building Inspector or the Zoning Inspector
determines a violation of this chapter upon inspection, which is, in the
opinion of such Building Inspector or Zoning Inspector, so dangerous as to
threaten life or serious physical injury to persons, such Inspector may
immediately shut off or disconnect any appliance, equipment or facility or
otherwise make the same inoperable. In which event the Inspector shall place a
red tag thereon, indicating that the appliance, equipment or facility shall not
be operated until repaired, modified or altered. Until necessary repairs,
alterations or modifications are made, and until further inspection and
approval by the Building Department the continued operation or use of any
appliance, equipment or facility after being "red tagged" as provided for
herein and without later repair, modification or alteration and subsequent
approval by the Building Department shall be deemed a violation of this
chapter.
(Ord. 61-1988. Passed 6-9-88.)
   1365.16  DEMOLITION INSURANCE.
   If, in the opinion of the Building Commissioner any building to be
demolished is so located that it may cause damage to public or private property
or persons, he shall require any applicant for a permit to demolish such
structure to file with the Inspector a property damage and public liability
insurance policy, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the
State and approved as to form by the Law Director. Such policy shall have
liability limits of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) and
shall indemnify the City for any damage the City may sustain by reason of
damage or injury to any highway, street or alley, sidewalk, fire hydrant or
other property of the City, which may be caused by or be incidental to the
demolition of any structure, and to indemnify the City against any claim of
damages to persons or private property.
(Ord. 6-1980. Passed 4-24-80.)
   1365.17  YARD HYDRANTS.
   Any newly constructed commercial building any portion of which is 300 feet
or more from the street shall be required to provide a yard hydrant or hydrants
as determined by the Fire Chief or Fire Prevention Officer.
   (a)   All yard hydrants shall meet the same standards and match the hydrants
existing within the City of Macedonia as to thread size and type, color of
paint and make up.
   (b)   All yard hydrants shall be supplied by a minimum eight (8) inch water
line.
   (c)   All yard hydrants will be subject to an acceptance test and an annual
inspection by the Fire Department.  These inspections will be done at no cost
to the owner.  The owner shall be responsible for repair of the hydrant(s) if
it fails to operate correctly. 
(Ord. 56-2004.  Passed 7-8-04.)
   1365.18  ALARM SYSTEMS.
   (a)   All new and existing motels, hotels, dormitories and apartments shall
have all fire alarm systems monitored by an off-site alarm company.
   (b)   All newly alarmed buildings will have pull stations at all exits.
(Ord. 56-2004.  Passed 7-8-04.)
   1365.99  PENALTY.
   (a)    Any owner, occupant, or other person who violates Section
1365.13(c) of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor.  Any
owner, occupant or other person who violates any other provision of this
chapter shall be deemed guilty of a second degree misdemeanor.
   (b)    Any organization as defined by Ohio R.C. 2901.23(D) shall be fined in
the  amount set forth above for any violation of this chapter. Any officer,
agent or  employee of such organization shall be subject to all penalties
prescribed herein in accordance with Ohio R.C. 2901.24 for any violation.
(Ord. 74-2017.  Passed 9-14-17.)
CHAPTER 1369
Plumbing
   EDITOR'S NOTE:  Pursuant to Ordinance 50-1979, passed May 10, 1979, the City
has authorized the Summit County Health Department to provide all plumbing
inspections within the City. There are no sections in Chapter 1369. This
chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references and for
future legislation.

CHAPTER 1373
Structures Under Construction
1373.01   Hazardous conditions prohibited.
1373.02   Abatement of nuisance.
1373.03   Revocation of permits; zoning certificates.
1373.04   Removal of structures.
1373.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
521.03
      Excavations - see S. U. & P. S. Ch.
905
      Architectural standards - see BLDG. Ch.
1341
   1373.01  HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS PROHIBITED.
   No owner or contractor of any building under construction shall cause,
suffer or permit any condition to exist upon property wherein a building is
under construction and prior to its occupancy which, in the opinion of the
Building Commissioner, is so dangerous as to threaten grave bodily harm or
death to residents particularly children who may be attracted to the area where
such dangerous condition is created.
(Ord. 103-1969. Passed 11-13-69.)
   1373.02  ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE.
   Such dangerous condition shall be abated and removed within five days of the
delivery by certified mail-return receipt requested of a written notice to the
owner or contractor at the address given by either on the application for
building permit and/or zoning certificate setting forth a description of the
hazardous condition and ordering its abatement or removal within five days of
the date of mailing of such notice. If the Building Commissioner personally
delivers the notice, the time limit shall be five days from the date of
delivery.
(Ord. 103-1969. Passed 11-13-69.)
   1373.03  REVOCATION OF PERMITS; ZONING CERTIFICATES.
   Any building permit and/or zoning certificate issued by the Building
Department or Zoning Inspector shall be revoked upon request of the Mayor if
the Mayor serves written notice to the Building Department and/or Zoning
Inspector that the owner or contractor has:
   (a)    Created a hazardous condition upon the premises which threatens grave
bodily harm or death to residents; and
   (b)    Failed to abate or remove such hazardous condition within five days
of the mailing or delivery of written notice to abate or remove such hazardous
condition. (Ord. 103-1969. Passed 11-13-69.)
   1373.04  REMOVAL OF STRUCTURES.
   Within thirty days after revocation of a building permit or zoning
certificate the owner or contractor shall remove any structure under
construction and regrade the land to a level surface. In the event that the
owner or contractor fails to remove such structure and/or regrade the land, the
Mayor may order such work done by a private contractor or City employee as he
deems necessary to remove any hazardous conditions, including, if necessary,
the removal of any structures. The cost of such work shall be billed to the
owner or contractor by written statement. If such statement is not paid within
thirty days after submission to the owner or contractor such costs shall be
certified to the County Auditor who shall place the same upon the tax duplicate
with all interest and penalties allowed by law and collected as other
delinquent taxes. (Ord. 103-1969. Passed 11-13-69.)
   1373.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever fails to abate or remove a hazardous condition within five days of
notification to do so shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day which
passes after the sixth day subsequent to such notification shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Ord. 103-1969. Passed 11-13-69.)
CHAPTER 1377
Swimming Pools
1377.01   Definitions.
1377.02   Enclosure of swimming pools.
1377.03   Maintenance of swimming pools.
1377.04   Modification.
1377.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Swimming pools - see OAC 3701-31
         Permit fee - see BLDG.
1321.05(e), 1321.08(p)
   1377.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense shall include the future; the
singular shall include the plural, and the plural the singular. The word
"shall" as used herein is mandatory and not merely directory.
   (a)    "Swimming pool; family" means a swimming pool used or intended to be
used solely by the owner or lessee thereof and his family, and by friends
invited to use it without payment of any fee.
   (b)    "Swimming pool; commercial" means a body of water in an artificial or
semi- artificial receptacle or other container, whether located indoors or
outdoors, used or intended to be used for public, semi-public or private
swimming by adults or children, or both adults and children, whether or not any
charge or fee is imposed upon such adults or children, operated and maintained
by any person as herein defined, whether he be an owner, lessee, operator,
licensee or concessionaire, exclusive of a family pool as defined in subsection
(a) hereof, and shall include all structures, appurtenances, equipment,
appliances and other facilities appurtenant to and intended for the operation
and maintenance of a swimming pool, and also all swimming pools operated and
maintained in conjunction with or by clubs, motels, hotels and community
associations.
      (Ord. 28-1963. Passed 6-25-63.)
   1377.02  ENCLOSURE OF SWIMMING POOLS.
   (a)    Every outdoor, in-ground commercial swimming pool or family pool
shall be completely surrounded by a fence or wall not less than four (4) feet
in height, which shall be so constructed as not to have openings, holes or gaps
larger than four (4) inches in any dimension except for doors and gates. If a
picket fence is erected or maintained, the horizontal dimension shall not
exceed four (4) inches. An accessory building may be used as part of such
enclosure, and a dwelling house may be used as a part of such enclosure of a
family pool.
   (b)    All gates or doors opening through such enclosure shall be equipped
with a self- closing and self-latching device for keeping the gate or door
securely closed at all times when not in actual use, except that the door of
any dwelling which forms a part of the enclosure need not be so equipped.
   (c)   Every outdoor, above-ground commercial or family swimming pool with a
height of forty-eight (48) inches or greater, measured from the ground upward,
and which is not contained in a fenced-in yard, must be:
      (1)   Equipped with retractable steps which may be locked, removed
entirely and/or otherwise secured in the upright position to prevent ingress;
or
      (2)   Equipped with a self-closing and self-locking gate or fence, forty-
eight (48) inches in height, which encloses the steps; or
      (3)   Equipped with a fence a minimum height of two (2) feet around the
top perimeter of the pool or spa, with retractable steps which may be locked or
otherwise secured in the upright position or which is equipped with a self-
closing and self-locking gate or fence, forty-eight (48) inches in height,
which encloses the steps.
   (d)    These requirements shall be applicable to all new commercial swimming
pools or family pools hereafter constructed, other than indoor pools, and shall
apply to all existing pools which have a minimum depth of eighteen (18) inches
of water. No person in possession of land, either as owner, purchaser, lessee,
tenant or a licensee, upon which is situated a commercial swimming pool or
family pool having a minimum depth of eighteen (18) inches shall fail to
provide and maintain such fence or wall as herein provided.
(Ord. 75-2017.  Passed 8-17-17.)
   1377.03 MAINTENANCE OF SWIMMING POOLS.
   (a)   All commercial swimming pools and family swimming pools shall be
maintained and kept in good working order so the water remains clear and free
of pollutants and debris, or drained and kept dry.
   (b)   Inoperable in-ground pools shall follow the “pool abandonment
procedures” as determined by the City Engineer. 
(Ord. 75-2017.  Passed 8-17-17.)
   1377.04  MODIFICATIONS.
   The Board of Zoning and Building Code Appeals may make modifications in
individual cases, upon a showing of good cause with respect to the height,
nature or location of the fence, wall, gates or latches, or the necessity
therefor, provided the protection as sought hereunder is not thereby reduced.
The Board may permit other protective devices or structures to be used so long
as the degree of protection afforded by the substitute devices or structures is
not less than the protection afforded by the wall, fence, gate and latch
described herein. The Board shall allow a reasonable period within which to
comply with the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 28-1963. Passed 6-25-63. )
   1377.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be a
separate offense.
CHAPTER 1381
Satellite Earth Stations
1381.01   Permit required.
1381.02   Application for permit; plans.
1381.03   Location.
1381.04   Support structures.
1381.05   Size.
1377.99   Penalty.
1381.06   Height.
1381.07   Exemptions.
1381.08   Permit fee.
1381.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Unauthorized CATV connections - see Ohio R.C. 4933.42
   1381.01  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall erect a dish-type, satellite signal-
receiving earth station in the City without first obtaining a conditional use
permit from the Planning Commission, unless the station is exempt under the
provisions of this chapter. The Planning Commission may grant a conditional use
for the construction and maintenance of such an earth station in any district
of the City in accordance with the provisions of Section
1137.04 of the Planning and Zoning Code provided the requirements enumerated in
this chapter are satisfied by the applicant. Where the requirements of this
chapter conflict with Section
1137.04, this chapter shall prevail.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
   1381.02  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; PLANS.
   (a)    Any person, firm or corporation which desires to construct a dish-
type, satellite signal-receiving earth station in the Municipality must apply
to the Planning Commission.
   (b)    The applicant must submit a written application upon a form provided
by the City, together with a plot plan of the lot or parcel of land, showing
the exact location of the proposed earth station, and the location of all
buildings and other structures on the lot or parcel and on other adjoining
lands, if structures are within fifty feet of any proposed earth station site;
a description of the type of earth station proposed to be installed; and a set
of construction plans and specifications which shall show the proposed
location, the height above the surface of the ground and in relation to other
structures, and which shall indicate the method of construction. Such set of
plans and specifications shall contain the name, address and phone number of
the person who prepared the plans and specifications.
   (c)    The application shall contain the names, addresses and phone numbers
of the applicant, the owner of the land, and the contractor who will perform
the installation of the earth station.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
   1381.03  LOCATION.
   (a)    No earth station shall be erected in any front yard.
   (b)    No earth station shall be erected in any side or rear yard which is
not in compliance with the yard requirements of the district in which the lot
is situated.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
   1381.04  SUPPORT STRUCTURES.
   (a)    Only metal support, galvanized construction, or equal thereto, shall
be allowed.
   (b)    Only a concrete base or caissons, depending on soil conditions, shall
be employed in line with grade.
   (c)    The structure shall be designed to withstand wind force of up to
eighty-five miles per hour in a manner conforming with good engineering
practices and procedures. A certificate shall be furnished to the Building
Commissioner, signed by a licensed and qualified engineer, that the
installation is in conformity to the above limitations.
   (d)    Any driving motor shall be encased in protective guards.
   (e)    All underground electrical wiring must be encased in rigid conduit at
a safe depth. Any overhead wiring must also meet the approval of the Electrical
Inspector.
   (f)    The earth station must be bonded to an eight foot grounding rod.
   (g)    Plans must meet all engineering practices and procedures.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
   1381.05  SIZE.
   The maximum diameter of any earth station shall not exceed eight feet.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
   1381.06  HEIGHT.
   The maximum height of any earth station structure shall not exceed ten feet
from natural grade level.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
   1381.07  EXEMPTIONS.
   Exempted from the provisions of this chapter are earth stations measuring
twenty-four inches in diameter or less.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
   1381.08  PERMIT FEE.
   The fee for a satellite dish earth station is forty dollars ($40.00).
(Ord. 95-2000.  Passed 12-28-00.)
   1381.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Ord. 29-1985. Passed 7-11-85.)
CHAPTER 1385
Dangerous Buildings

         Occupancy inspections - see BLDG. Ch.
1325
         Maintenance standards - see BLDG. Ch.
1365
   1385.01  DANGEROUS BUILDINGS; NUISANCES.
   As used in this chapter, all dangerous buildings, within the terms of this
section are hereby declared and shall be deemed to be public nuisances by
reason of the condition in which the same are permitted to be or remain, and
which shall or may endanger the health, life, limb or property, or cause any
hurt, harm, inconvenience, discomfort, damage or injury to any one or more
persons in the City, in any one or more of the following particulars:
   (a)    By reason of being a nuisance to the general health of the community.
   (b)    By reason of being a fire hazard.
   (c)    By reason of being unsafe for occupancy or use on, in, upon, about or
around the aforesaid premises.
   (d)    By reason of being a nuisance, because of long-continued vacancy,
lack of reasonable or adequate maintenance of structure and/or premises
adjacent thereto, thereby depreciating the enjoyment and use of property in the
immediate vicinity to such an extent that it is harmful to the community in
which such structure is situated.
      (Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.02  DANGEROUS BUILDING DEFINED.
   All buildings or structures which have any or all of the following defects
shall be deemed "dangerous buildings":
   (a)    Those whose interior walls or other vertical structural members list,
lean or  buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing through the center
of gravity  falls outside of the middle third of its base.
   (b)    Those which, exclusive of the foundation, show thirty-three percent
(33%) or more of damage or deterioration of the supporting member or members,
or fifty percent (50%) of damage or deterioration of the nonsupporting
enclosing or outside walls or covering.
   (c)    Those which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors or
roofs or in which the same are overloaded, or which have insufficient strength
to be reasonably safe for the purpose used.
   (d)    Those which have been damaged by fire, wind or other causes so as to
have become dangerous to life, safety, morals or the general health and welfare
of the occupants or the people of the City.
   (e)    Those which have become or are so dilapidated, decayed, unsafe,
unsanitary or which so utterly fail to provide the amenities essential to
decent living that they are unfit for human habitation, or are likely to cause
sickness or disease, so as to cause injury to the health, morals, safety or
general welfare of those living therein.
   (f)    Those having light, air and sanitation facilities which are
inadequate to protect the health, morals, safety or general welfare of human
beings who live or may live therein.
   (g)    Those having inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or
panic, or those having insufficient stairways, elevators, fire escapes or other
means of communication.
   (h)    Those which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may
fall and injure members of the public or property.
   (i)    Those which, because of their condition, are unsafe, unsanitary or
dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the people of the
City.
   (j)    Those buildings existing in violation of any provisions of this
Building Code, any provision of the Fire Prevention Code or other ordinances of
the City.
   (k)    Those buildings which are vacant and unguarded at the doors or
windows.
      (Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.03  STANDARDS FOR REPAIR, VACATION OR DEMOLITION.
   The following standards shall be followed in substance by the Building
Commissioner in ordering the repair, vacation or demolition:
   (a)    If the dangerous building or structure can reasonably be repaired so
that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this chapter, it
shall be ordered repaired.
   (b)    If the dangerous building or structure is in such condition as to
make it dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the
occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated.
   (c)    In any case where a dangerous building or structure requires repairs
or restoration, or is damaged, decayed or deteriorated in excess of fifty
percent (509c) of its replacement value, exclusive of foundations, it shall be
made to comply in all respects with the current requirements for materials and
methods of construction or it shall be demolished. In all cases where a
building cannot be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the
terms of this chapter, it shall be demolished. In all cases where a dangerous
building is a fire hazard existing or erected in violation of the terms of this
chapter or any other ordinance of the City or State statute, it shall be
demolished.
      (Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.04  AUTHORITY TO EXAMINE PREMISES.
   The Building Commissioner or a person delegated by him shall be empowered to
examine or cause to be examined any building or structure within the City, to
determine whether such building or structure is dangerous, unsafe or
constitutes a nuisance, as provided herein.
(Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.05  REMEDIAL ORDER.
   Whenever the Building Commissioner finds any building or structure or
portion thereof to be dangerous, unsafe or a public nuisance as defined in this
chapter, he shall give written notice to the owners of an interest of record,
including any purchasers under a land sale contract and the persons occupying
the building if they are not the owners thereof. The notice shall be written
and specifically state the defects that cause the building to be unsafe and
shall require the owner within a stated time not to exceed six months either to
complete specified repairs or improvements or to demolish and remove the
building or structure or portion thereof, leaving the premises in a clean, safe
and sanitary condition, such condition being subject to the approval of the
Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.06  SERVICE OF NOTICE.
   (a)    Proper service of the notice set forth in Section
1385.05 shall be by certified mail, or personal service; provided, however,
that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof is
sent by certified mail to the owner's last known address. If a party cannot be
located, nor his address ascertained, this notice shall be deemed to be
properly served if a copy thereof is placed in a conspicuous place in or about
the building structure affected by such notice and further, a copy of this
notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in this county
for a period of three consecutive days.
   (b)    It shall be the duty of any owner or agent or person in control of
such structure or building, mortgagee of record or lien holders of record who
have received a notice of violation as provided for in this section to inform
prospective purchasers, vendees, grantees, assignees or land contractees
thereof of any such notice of violation or the notice to repair or rehabilitate
or demolish and remove. No owner or agent or person in control of such
structure or building, mortgagee of record or lien holders of record shall
transfer to vendee, grantee, assignee or land contractee or any other
transferee any interest in such structure or building after receiving a notice
of violation or notice to repair or rehabilitate or demolish and remove without
first providing the transferee with a copy of such notice.
   (c)    If such notice is by certified mail, the time period within which the
owner is required to comply with the order of the Building Commissioner shall
begin as of the date he receives such notice.
(Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.07  VACATION OF PREMISES.
   (a)    If necessary, the notice provided for in Section
1385.05 shall also require the building, structure or portion thereof, to be
vacated forthwith and not reoccupied or used until the specified repairs and
improvements are completed, inspected and approved by the Building
Commissioner.  Such notice shall read:
   "Do Not Enter. Unsafe to Occupy. Building Department, City of Macedonia."
   (b)    Such notice shall remain posted until the required repairs are made
or demolition is completed. No person shall remove such notice without
permission of the Building Commissioner or enter the building except for the
purpose of making the required repairs or demolishing the same.
(Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.08  PERMITS.
   In all cases of construction or repair pursuant to orders of the Building
Commissioner, permits covering such work shall be obtained as required by other
sections of this Building Code.
(Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.09  APPEALS.
   Any person adversely affected by any order of the Building Commissioner to
vacate, repair or demolish a building may appeal that decision or order to the
Board of Zoning and Building Code Appeals by filing a written request with the
Chairman of the Board within ten (10) days after the issuance of the order. 
The appeal would then proceed according to Section
1135.05 of the Codified Ordinances. 
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 6-23-05.)
   1385.10  FAILURE TO ACT; REMEDY BY CITY; COSTS CERTIFIED AS LIEN.
   If any person fails to comply with any lawful order of the Building
Commissioner, or, in the case of an appeal, any final order of Council, within
the time limit specified in such order, the Building Commissioner shall request
Council to cause such building to be vacated, repaired or demolished, as the
facts may warrant, under the standards provided for in this chapter. Council,
with the assistance of the Director of Finance shall cause the costs of such
vacation, repair or demolition, including the costs of service or publication
of notice, to be certified to the Clerk of Council, who shall certify the
aforesaid costs to the County Auditor, together with a proper description of
the premises for placing the same on the tax duplicate, together with all
interest and penalties allowed by law. From the date of entry, a lien shall
vest on the premises in accordance with Ohio R.C. 715.261.
(Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.11  NOTICE TO OWNER OF INTENT TO DEMOLISH.
   (a)    When determined that an emergency exists, prior to the City invoking
the provisions of Section
1385.10, Council shall cause written notice of such intent to such person or
persons as provided in subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)    Notice shall be served in the same manner as provided in Section
1385.06, informing the owner or agent, mortgagee of record and lien holders of
record of the City's intention to demolish and remove the unsafe building or
structure, at least thirty days prior to such intended action by the City.
(Ord. 34-1986. Passed 8-14-86.)
   1385.99  PENALTY.
   (a)    The owner of any dangerous building who fails to comply with any
notice or order to repair, vacate or demolish such building, given by any
person authorized by this chapter to give such notice or order, shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor of the third degree. Each day which there is a failure to
comply shall constitute a separate violation.
   (b)   The occupant of lessee in possession who fails to comply with any
notice to vacate and who fails to repair such building in accordance with any
notice given, as provided in this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.  Each day which there is a failure to comply shall constitute
a separate violation.
(Ord. 56-2005.  Passed 6-23-05.)
CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF MACEDONIA

CHAPTER 1501
Explosives
1501.01   Definitions.
1501.02   General requirements.
1501.03   Blasting bond.
